block.p: Pakistan Broadens Crackdown on Militants The government has rounded up 1,430 people and sealed 390 offices of militant groups as part of a widening crackdown on extremists ordered by President Pervez Musharraf, a senior police official said. Despite the action, India's defense minister said India was ready for war if Pakistan did not act quickly enough. India accuses Pakistan-based Islamic militants of attacking Indian targets.

Palestinian Militia Leader Killed Raed al-Karmi, the leader of a local Palestinian militia, was killed by a bomb hidden near his house. Within hours, Palestinian gunmen ambushed Israeli soldiers in the West Bank, killing one soldier.
Drawing criticism at home and abroad, the Israeli authorities demolished nine Palestinian homes in East Jerusalem, saying they had been built without permits.
Colombia Peace Talks Revived Rebels and the government of President Andr√©s Pastrana came to a final-hour agreement to restart stalled peace talks and avoid a wider war.
Meeting on Zimbabwe African leaders pressed President Robert Mugabe to abandon violence and intimidation as his troubled country lurches toward elections.

U.N. Seeks Foreign Aid To Pay Afghan Bills The United Nations urged foreign governments to increase their financial donations in light of the inability of Afghanistan's interim government to pay its workers and with foreign aid only trickling in.
Search for Anthrax Clues Federal agents have examined copying machines at Rutgers for possible links to the anthrax mailer, a scientist at the New Jersey campus said.

Suits Against Airlines Four liability lawsuits have been filed against airlines and security companies arising from the Sept. 11 attacks, raising questions about whether a moratorium on suits is eroding.
Curbs Sought on Security Talk The new head of the Transportation Security Administration complained that government officials had hurt security since Sept. 11 by talking too much about their methods.
Easing Emergency Measures Many police departments are ready to scale back changes made right after the Sept. 11 attacks.

Doctors Charge a Premium For Better Patient Service Two Boston physicians have stirred discussion with a plan to open a practice that will charge patients $4,000 a year on top of the medical costs covered by their health insurance for premium service that will include round-the-clock cell phone access.

Ex-Priest in Sex Abuse Trial Jury selection began for a former Roman Catholic priest, John J. Geoghan, 66, who is charged with molesting a 10-year-old boy at a suburban Boston parish. He faces a second trial next month and a third is yet to be scheduled. All told, more than 130 people have accused him of molesting children during a 30-year period.

Father Who Fled Is Caught Christian Michael Longo, a fugitive wanted in connection with the deaths of his wife and three children in Oregon, was captured in Mexico late Sunday and flown to Houston to await transfer to Oregon. Mr. Longo, 27, was put on the F.B.I.'s list of the 10 most-wanted fugitives last week.

Medical Scrutiny for Bush The White House physician said he would monitor President Bush in the next few days to ensure that the fainting episode he experienced on Sunday was due to a nervous system reaction to choking and not to any underlying medical problem.
Wetland Rules Revised The Bush administration said it would ease some Clinton administration regulations covering wetlands and streams.

2 Troopers Plead Guilty In Racial Profiling Case Two New Jersey troopers, John Hogan, 32, and James Kenna, 31, pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges and were spared jail time and probation for wounding three unarmed men during a turnpike traffic stop in 1998. The troopers, who are white, said that they had stopped the van because its occupants were black and Latino and that police supervisors had told them that black and brown-skinned drivers were more likely to be drug traffickers.

Giuliani Altered Team Leases Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani quietly amended the leases of the city's two major league baseball teams, giving the Yankees an easy out if the city did not follow through with Mr. Giuliani's stadium plan and releasing the Mets from paying the city large sums of ad money.

Pataki Health Plan Rebuff The Democratic majority in the State Assembly rejected Governor Pataki's request to pass a complex health care bill to raise the salaries of hospital workers by financing the increases in part with a $1 billion windfall from an insurance company.

Underground Fire Menace Fires are burning in thousands of underground coal seams from Pennsylvania to Mongolia, releasing toxic gases, adding millions of tons of heat-trapping carbon dioxide to the atmosphere and killing vegetation.

A Brother's Sacrifice A healthy 57-year-old man died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital from complications following an operation in which he donated part of his liver to provide a transplant for his brother. The brother, 54, is recovering.
N.F.L. Coaching Ranks Roiled Tampa Bay, which has been courting Bill Parcells, fired Tony Dungy. Washington named Steve Spurrier to replace Marty Schottenheimer.

An Early Warning at Enron An Enron executive told the chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, in August that improper accounting practices threatened to bring down the company, Congressional investigators said. The letter, written anonymously, roughly coincided with Mr. Lay's assurances to employees and investors that Enron's stock would rebound.
Mr. Lay used his company stock to repay a loan last year, an Enron lawyer said. The disclosure indicated that Mr. Lay had shed more of his holdings than previously disclosed.
Europe Wins Tax Policy Dispute A World Trade Organization appeals panel ruled that offshore tax havens allowed by United States tax law amounted to an illegal trade subsidy and must be scrapped.
Sunbeam Stock Suit Settled Albert J. Dunlap and other former executives agreed to pay $15 million to end a stockholder lawsuit accusing them of inflating stock prices.
